message.content:
After someone enters and kills one of the initial three, there would still be two people remaining who could potentially commit murder—the original killers not killed yet plus the new person if they decide to become a third killer (since "killer" does not necessarily mean that all participants in violence have been identified as criminals).

However, traditionally this riddle plays on semantics and assumes an interpretation of 'kill' where only those who commit murder are considered killers. If we interpret the question strictly according to legal definitions—where a killer is someone convicted or guilty of murder—then if one has been killed but not legally charged (only shot in self-defense), then there would be two remaining individuals: the original three and the new person who entered, assuming they did nothing.

---
